response.answer_text: This is the classic “set-up” question. It sets up the Christian salvation doctrine of exclusivity as appearing to be unfair and unjust, let alone dogmatically parochial and intolerant. “If you don’t join our club you’re going to burn in hell forever”… hahahahaha… (diabolical laughter added for effect) What if what Christians believe and what is written in the Bible is actually true? What if it is not something man-made… a man-made doctrine, but it is actually true? What if Jesus Christ is really God come to earth to save the race of sinners… i.e. human beings that have all rejected God , their Creator as indeed being God their Creator. What if sin was the cost of giving us all freedom to have our own wills independent from the will of the One who created us? What if as a result we all blow it big time - because we all- in essence- are addicted to being our own little gods? What if that is all true? If it is then God might have His own exclusive plan and means of opening a door back to fellowship with Him. It just might be a plan He has communicated and executed. Here is the bottom line - if you can and would believe it: Human beings are all equally fallen away from fellowship with God. Each one of us can look at the “norm” of relationship with God the Father in the Son, Jesus Christ. Reading the book of John can give one a perspective of how disconnected we are from the fellowship norm with our God by looking at Jesus’ relationship with His Heavenly Father. We all have sinned and fallen short of the glory of God. Even worse we all are born into this sin, congenitally inheriting the original of Adam and Eve. We therefore end up cultivating our own hell with the desires that burn within us during our short stay in this short life. If the afterlife is basically two dualistic options… i.e. reward or punishment… Our reward would be having our cultivated earthly desires fulfilled forevermore (heaven) or our cultivated earthly desires unfulfilled endlessly (hell). My answer to this question: … if God is the reward at the end of this short life and we are cultivating a love for God, we will have heaven in our grasp. If we are cultivating desires other than God - we are cultivating an afterlife of hell. The question is then how does one cultivate a love for God in this life?… and even more… does one even want to? If the Gospel is true than the only way is to have God Himself cleanse us of our sinful desires for something other than Him and give us His own Spirit that enables us to love Him in this life and forever more. Jesus Christ died for our sins, taking them upon Himself and in return giving us Himself… this transaction is done simply through believing it from the heart… this is very Good News! …a work and sign of God’s grace and mercy in your life. The question then does not in the end rest on answering some theological or philosophical debate, but simply … Can you believe it? Do you believe this?

You are asking two separate questions: (1) Are non-Christians allowed into heaven; AND (2) what does "Christian scripture" have to say about whether non-Christians are allowed into heaven? Which is a nonsense-question, since Christianity did not exist when ANY of the Bible was put into writing; even the Christian Testament was written by Jews, and a few "pagans," 200 to 300 years before "Christianity" evolved. Here are some more questions: What is heaven? Does everyone agree on what heaven is? Has everyone on Earth ever agreed on what heaven is? Has anyone been to heaven and returned to tell us what heaven is like? If so, how do we know the alleged returnee was not crazy, deluded, or hallucinating? (Buffy the Vampire Slayer does not count, alas.) If you're a bibliolater — that is, if you believe that the Bible, a human artifact, is as perfect and "inerrant" as God is — you need to be able to explain Sheol, Hades, Gehenna, Abaddon, Tartarus, "hell," Paradise, the "third heaven," and "ordinary" heaven, all of which appear in the Bible as afterlife destinations for humans whether or not those humans jumped through the hoops prescribed by followers of the Christian Testament. The myths that most people believe in today, the harps and wings and haloes on the one hand and the fiery pit of eternal agony on the other, both have virtually nothing to do with either the Bible or what may or may not happen to living creatures when they die. God is perfect and thus perfectly good. God is everywhere ("omnipresent"). If God is everywhere, that means there is no place, either literal or metaphorical, where God is not. In other words, if hell exists, God is there, right this minute, suffering the torments of damnation right alongside those who are condemned.  I do not, myself, believe that God is a masochist. When I was in seminary, one of my professors remarked that whether or not you believe in hell, you don't have to believe hell has any occupants. A different professor commented that she had no idea how any Christian could be happy in heaven, knowing that other people were being tortured for all eternity — for "crimes" like eating a strip of bacon on a Friday before the pope gave you permission to, for example. I believe that "God is love" (1 John 4:8). If God is good and God is love, it doesn't matter where I "go" after I die: God will be present with me, and it will therefore be good. And if God is NOT good and God is NOT everywhere and God does NOT love all of God's creation, then I don't care what happens after I die; in that case, I hope I just dissolve into nothingness.

First, some answers are from Christians, some from those who are apparently not. The question is phrased seemingly to solicit "Christian" answers.  A very "hot button" question. In a broad sense, Christianity certainly provides for people who lived before Jesus Christ being either sinners, but "pleasing in the sight of the Lord" (e.g. Abraham, Joseph, David, etc.) or "wicked sinners before the Lord (Ahab and Jezebel, etc.). This would seem to suggest that one could at least be "pleasing" to the Lord, or at least that He countenanced their earthly efforts at pleasing Him, versus those who overtly displeased Him.  However, it is also noted that, once Christ was resurrected, and the Gospel began to be preached, Christianity made it clear that (whatever "works of righteousness" we might properly and rightly perform), salvation is by faith in Christ as savior. In other words, we cannot "work our way into Heaven" or in any way "earn" salvation by dint of sheer effort. We are "forgiven", truly, by God's good pleasure, through the shed blood of Christ and His atonement. There is no question of "paying God back" for our sins, or "working off our debts".  But not everyone who has ever lived has heard the Gospel message. When the question comes up as to "What about those who never heard?", many otherwise conservative Christians become contentious. I have heard bible-believing Christians who will flatly state that, "except they believe, they cannot be saved", who then conclude that people who lived outside the range of the Gospel are damned. For me, this seems far too "doctrinaire" and unjust, and unworthy of God, Who is benevolent and merciful toward all men, and does not take pleasure in judgement or punishment. One sometimes finds this belief among those who are often called "Calvinists", since (in keeping with their theories of soteriology... "how salvation works") they believe that no person "accepts" the Gospel of their own will. Rather, God "elects" some to belief and salvation. Hence, for them, the damnation of a Indian peasant who lived 500 years before Christ is no "injustice", for the American businessman of today would not "come to faith" unless God selected him for such.  This, I must confess, seems not only inordinately unjust and unmerciful, but also extremely contrived. The thoughts of someone who is more concerned that their understanding of doctrine and scripture "all adds up", even if it means that countless millions who are no more sinners than we are, should be arbitrarily dropped into Hell. My own thoughts (for what little they are worth) are that God will use the Christian era to establish principles of salvation which will, on Judgement Day, then be applied to all that ever lived. There will be people who did not "hear the Gospel" (as we understand it), as they lived before or outside its range. But there was always a "God-given yearning for it in their hearts" and, upon hearing it, they will always rejoice in it. (Do not missionaries often find this to be the case... that when the message of Christ is first preached in an area, there is an immediate rejoicing of some upon hearing it, while others are seemingly indifferent or hostile?) In any event, since the observable consequences are the same... some receive it, some do not... the "Arminian vs. Calvinist" debate would seem very difficult to resolve "empirically". After all, what man could possibly "see" what the Holy Spirit of God is secretly doing in someone's heart? One cannot tell what a person who has heard the Gospel "would have done" if they had not ever heard it. We must, in faith, leave such matters to the wisdom of God Himself and, for our part, do the best we can to carry out His instructions to us in this life.  But both sides of the debate will tell you this... If you have heard the offer of salvation, rightly presented, warning of impending judgement from God against all sin, and if you know yourself to be a sinner, then the question of what becomes of "non-Christians" is simply no longer relevant to you. If by "non-Christian", one means (as I have interpreted it) "a person who simply has never heard the Gospel of Christ about repentance and salvation through faith", then you are not in that class. People in the western world today are (with perhaps a few exceptions here and there) NOT "ignorant" of the doctrines of human sinfulness, of coming judgement against all sin, and of the offer of salvation through faith in Christ. Those in the civilized world today are thus not "naive non-Christians". They are, rather, "anti-Christians". In fact, I am seeing, with increasing frequency, a tendency for people to refer to themselves specifically as "anti-theists". For such people as those.... no. There is, in the light of the Christian Gospel, no hope for such persons at all. They have certainly sinned. They have certainly condemned and judged sin in others, while allowing and excusing it in themselves. They will, therefore, inevitably incur God's wrath and judgement. And they will not be able to say that they were not warned. A very big (and dreadful) difference between "ignorance" and "rejection".

Justification has often been defined as "Just as if I'd never sinned." This thought conveys forgiveness, acquittal of the past sin at the time of new birth.But justification goes even further: God positively declares the person to be righteous. When God justifies us, His forgiveness does not merely make us neutral—moral and spiritual zeroes. His forgiveness brings Him to look on us "in Christ," as having His perfect righteousness. He credits or assigns Christ's righteousness to the trusting person. This does not make one personally righteous, but it declares that person righteous in a legal sense, his debt has been paid, his sins have been forgiven, and he is brought into right relationship with God. Paul stresses that we cannot be justified by the works of the law, for "no one will be declared righteous in his [God's] sight by observing the law; rather, through the law we become conscious of sin" (Rom. 3:20). He goes on to explain: "[We] are justified freely by his [God's] grace through the redemption that came by Christ Jesus" (Rom. 3:24). The basis, or ground, of our justification, or being declared righteous, is twofold. • Christ's death as our substitute satisfied the claims of God's holy Law against our sin: 'While we were still sinners, Christ died for us. Since we have now been justified by his blood, how much more shall we be saved from God's wrath through him!" (Rom. 5:9) • God assigns us Christ's righteousness, based on His perfect obedience: "Just as through the disobedience of the one man [Adam] the many [all people] were made sinners, so also through the obedience of the one man [Christ] the many [all who believe] will be made righteous" (Rom. 5:19). Christ became identified with us when He was made sin for us on the cross. When we believe, we are given His newness of resurrection life, and we share His righteousness. Justification comes by faith. This truth burst upon the heart and mind of Martin Luther like a bombshell after a lengthy, unsuccessful struggle with self-flagellation to win God's favor. He saw the magnitude of the one truth: "The righteous will live by faith" (Rom. 1:17). He saw it was not what he could do to merit God's favor, but what God had already done for him at the cross. There Christ made justification and peace possible. The Protestant Reformation grew out of this discovery. Paul E. The New Testament writings, including the Gospels, reflect a tension between exclusivity (only Christians allowed into heaven) and inclusivity (Christ's sacrifice was sufficient to reconcile everyone to God). In the Gospel of St Mark you'll find: “He that believes and is baptized shall be saved; but he who does not believe shall be damned” which is an exclusive statement, however in 1 Timothy you'll find: "...we have put our hope in the  living God, who is the Savior of all, and especially of those who believe" which counts both believers and non-believers in God's saving act. The writers of the Gospels, Acts and the Pauline letters struggled to understand the significance of His death and resurrection, and how far God's grace is extended through it. This tension is also found in the writings of the early Church as well. Origen and Gregory of Nyssa wrote about the "apokatastasis" or the ultimate reconciliation of all things to God at the end of time.  The more contemporary writings of Hans Kung, Karl Rahner who labeled non-believers "anonymous Christians" (in other words Christians who don't know it yet) and others, explore this as well. The Vatican issued a teaching in Dominus Iesus that touches on the salvation of non-Christians which Pope John Paul II later clarfied by writing: "This confession does not deny salvation to non-Christians, but points  to its ultimate source in Christ, in whom man and God are united.".  This is one of those doctrines that can' t be proven by simple prooftexting. One problem, is that the Gospels often use poetic language (in a language completely unrelated to English) which doesn't lend itself to literalism. Many Christians translate phrases like "Kingdom of God" or "eternal life" as meaning "heaven", "lake of fire" or "Gehenna" meaning "hell", and "saved" meaning going to heaven when 1st Century Jewish Christians may not have necessarily understood or used these words in this way. There is also an assumption (which isn't supported by scripture, which is silent on this matter) that God cannot work God's grace beyond the grave. In other words, once you die, that's it. You can't grow or change.  Most Christians would agree that Christ is the gatekeeper. "No one comes to the Father but through me" however whether this means only professing Christians, or whether others will be let through that gate, is ultimately in God's hands not ours. The Eastern Orthodox say: "We know where Christ is, but we don't know where Christ isn't" and leave it at that. Christians should be in the salvation business, not the damnation business.  I believe that God's grace overcomes all our limitations - even those of us (which will be everyone in some way, myself included) who believe things that will ultimately turn out to be wrong. At the same time I wouldn't identify myself as a universalist because I believe that God endowed us with free-will, which means we can choose to live apart from God, assuming that we fully understand that choice and still desire to do so - something that may not be possible given our limitations here on Earth. It's hard for me to believe that people can't grow or change beyond the grave, so that perhaps over time, many in hell will accept Christ's call, simply walk out of it and into heaven. Because of that it remains my hope that, while I believe that eternal Hell exists, it will ultimately be empty.

I originally posted this as a comment, but thought it was long enough and probably worth posting as a full answer: Christ is not one of many paths. He said this himself:“ I am THE way, and THE truth, and THE life. NO ONE comes to the Father EXCEPT THROUGH ME.” (John 14:6) This does not take much explaining; if Christ is who He said He is, then He must be the only way that anybody can get to heaven. This message is repeated by Peter, who said “And there is salvation in NO ONE else, for there is NO OTHER NAME under heaven given among men by which we must be saved.” (Acts 4:12) With regards to the common claim that all religions teach the golden rule, this does not prove the truth of those religions or that they are a path that leads to heaven. As good as it is, following the golden rule has never and will never earn anybody a place in heaven. Think about it. Have you ever treated anybody else in a way that you would not like to be treated? If the answer is yes, then you have just proven your own guilt before God, who gave us the golden rule. The golden rule is not the only law given by God, but, even so, it is still enough to show that you deserve to go to hell. “for all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God” (Romans 3:23). If it is true that you have broken the golden rule (or any other law given in scripture or revealed through your conscience), then you have proven yourself incapable of earning your way into heaven. No amount of trying to improve yourself will work because YOU HAVE FAILED BEFORE YOU HAVE EVEN STARTED. Even if you lived the rest of your life perfectly (if you think you can, good luck!), you would still be sent to hell for the times earlier in your life when you didn’t live perfectly. The only hope in this case is forgiveness, which leads to my next point. God is a perfectly fair judge; He will never give a punishment where there is no sin and will never withhold punishment where there is sin. The first is easy to agree to. I can assume that we both agree that if I am taken to court and it is proven that I am innocent but the judge fines me anyway that the judge is a bad judge. The second is more controversial, but most people will admit it after some thought. If your close friend was murdered and the murderer was taken to court and found guilty, you would be very angry if the judge let them off with a £50 fine. The judge in this case was bad because he didn’t uphold justice, which is his role as a judge. In the same way, as a good judge, God can’t let any sin go unpunished. Which leads to the question: how can God forgive us? The only possible solution to this is for somebody to step forward and switch places with the criminal (us). This is known in Christian theology as penal substitution. The substitute takes upon himself the guilty record of the offender and gives the offender their good record. The substitute, who is now legally a criminal, is punished for the crime of the offender. Once this punishment is complete, the sin is dealt with and the judge no longer has to give any more punishment; both the offender and the substitute are free from the law because its demands have been met. The big question now is who is are substitute? The bible teaches that it is Jesus Christ. “For our sake he [Jesus] made him to be sin who knew no sin, so that in him we might become the righteousness of God.” This verse shows how Jesus is counted as having committed the sins of Christians and Christians are counted as having lived as good a life as Jesus, even though they haven’t. This shows that Christians don’t (some do, but shouldn’t!) believe themselves to be better than other people because they are going to heaven instead of hell. The reason for this is that Jesus earned our way into heaven, not us. All that we did was earn punishment for Jesus on the cross. As Jonathan Edwards put it: “You contribute nothing to your salvation except the sin that made it necessary.” So, back to the question, the answer is NO. Not because Christians are better than other people, but because our sins were paid for on the cross by Jesus. Anybody who repents of their sin and truly follows Jesus will go to heaven. “Everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved.” (Romans 10:13)
